title-group.article-title: Development of Chemistry-Based Laminar Flame Speed Correlation for Part-Load SI Conditions and Validation in a GDI Research Engine

abstract.p: The detailed study of part-load conditions is essential to characterize engine-out emissions in key operating conditions. The relevance of part-load operations is further emphasized by the recent regulations such as the new WLTP standard.

Combustion development at part-load operations depends on a complex interplay between moderate turbulence levels (low engine speed and tumble ratio), low in-cylinder pressure and temperature, and stoichiometric-to-lean mixture quality (to maximize fuel efficiency). From a modelling standpoint, the reduced turbulence intensity compared to full-load operations complicates the interaction between different sub-models (e.g., reconsideration of the flamelet hypothesis adopted by common combustion models).

In this article, the authors focus on chemistry-based simulations for laminar flame speed of gasoline surrogates at conditions typical of part-load operations. The analysis is an extension of a previous study focused on full-load operations. The methodology is based on detailed chemistry 1D simulations of the flame structure. The comparison with the previous research reveals that flames at partial loads experience analogous temperature levels, despite the generally lower pressure. Therefore, particular attention will be devoted to the temperature scaling of flame speed, as well as to the extension to lean mixtures.

A correlation is proposed for laminar flame speed, and it is applied to simulate the combustion development on a single-cylinder research engine operated at 0.7 bar absolute pressure part-load condition. The engine is provided with an optical access to the combustion chamber, allowing a detailed comparison of the flame development since early flame kernel growth. The relevance of an accurate laminar flame speed modelling is then discussed in details.
The correlation for laminar flame speed proposed by the authors constitutes a useful reference for similar studies, and it can be used in conjunction with the most common CFD combustion models.

caption.p: p,Tu traces for all the operating conditions considered from spark time to peak pressure. Red dots: engine conditions (ECs) used for sL calculations. © SAE International

Commercial gasolines and surrogates’ compositions: RD387 [33], Exxon 708629 [22], Total TAE 7000 [30], Gasoline EU5 E95 (present study), Dirrenberger’s surrogate [30] and Gauthier’s Surrogate A [27]. © SAE International
Research octane number for the gasoline fuels and surrogates considered in the present study. © SAE International

Calculated sL for four different fuel models (mechanism/blend) against experimental data from [13], Tu=373 K and the following four pressure levels: 10 bar, 15 bar, 20 bar, and 25 bar. Green solid line represents Metghalchi and Keck’s correlation [6] prediction, while orange solid line represents the target for the polynomial fit. © SAE International

Calculated sL for two different fuel models (mechanism/blend) and Metghalchi and Keck’s correlation [6] against experimental data from [22] at 1 bar and three temperature levels: 298 K, 328 K, and 358 K. © SAE International
Calculated power exponent α for the chosen fuel models against the experimental one for a commercial gasoline [22] and the one predicted by Metghalchi and Keck’s correlation [6]. © SAE International
Simulated dataset of sL for 15 bar and 670 K for gasoline surrogate over the range of equivalence ratio Φ = 0.4 – 2.0 and EGR = 0 % – 10 %. © SAE International

Relative fitting error of polynomials of Equation 4 against calculated sL data for gasoline. The target value for the fitting procedure is the averaged value of the results obtained with the two fuel models previously chosen for a given (p, Tu, Φ, EGR) condition. © SAE International

Normalized sL values for Φ < 0.7 obtained from the chemical kinetics simulations for three selected ECs considered. Dot colors represent the pressure level, while dot shapes represent the three temperature levels considered (low, medium, and high). © SAE International

Dependence of normalized sL values on equivalence ratio and normalized temperature (Tref = 550 K) for Φ < 0.7. Dot shapes represent the equivalence ratios while colors represent the three temperature levels considered (low, medium, and high). © SAE International
Lean mixtures’ slope coefficient m (above) and y-axis intercept coefficient q (below) dependence on equivalence ratio for the three temperature levels. © SAE International
Correlation between sL values obtained using pressure scaling (PS) and combined temperature-pressure scaling (TPS) for Φ<0.7. © SAE International
Normalized sL values predicted by pressure scaling (PS) and temperature-pressure scaling approach (TPS) for Φ < 0.7 for 35 bar. © SAE International

Normalized sL values predicted by pressure scaling (PS) and temperature-pressure scaling approach (TPS) for Φ < 0.7 for 30 bar. Black-dashed data represent the calculated values, while blue and red lines represent calculated

with PS and TPS methodologies, respectively. © SAE International

Dependence of normalized sL values on Φ and normalized temperature (Tref = 550 K) for Φ > 1.4. Dot shapes represent the Φ value while colors represent the temperature level considered (low, medium, and high). © SAE International
Rich mixtures’ slope coefficient m (above) and y-axis intercept coefficient q (below) dependence on Φ for the three temperature levels (low, medium, and high). © SAE International
Correlation between sL values obtained using pressure scaling and combined pressure-temperature scaling for Φ > 1.4. © SAE International

Normalized sL values predicted by pressure scaling (PS) and temperature-pressure scaling approach (TPS) for Φ > 1.4 and 5 bar pressure condition. Black-dashed data represent the calculated values while blue and red lines are calculated with PS and TPS methodologies, respectively. © SAE International
Calculated sL data and polynomial fitting form from Equation 10 (for Φ < 0.7), Equation 4 (for 0.7 < Φ < 1.4), and Equation 17 (for Φ > 1.4) for gasoline at four selected ECs. © SAE International
Schematic representation of the experimental setup and illustration of the optical access. © SAE International
Engine specifications © SAE International
Fuel properties and PIONA characterization © SAE International
Flame front evolution detected via UV-visible imaging (top), flame outline (middle), and binary images (bottom) obtained through image processing. © SAE International
3D CFD computational grid. The model includes the combustion chamber, intake and exhaust ports, and the crevice between piston and liner. © SAE International

3D CFD mean in-cylinder pressure (top), cumulative apparent heat release rate (center), and apparent heat release rate (bottom) curves against experimental data during the combustion process. © SAE International
Main combustion indicators based on the effective mass fraction burnt for the experimental and the 3D CFD cases. © SAE International

Comparison between the experimental and calculated flame area as function of the crank angle degree after spark onset. Experimental optical limit is highlighted by the dashed black line. © SAE International
Ratio between simulated and experimental (averaged over 100 consecutive cycles) flame area at 15 and 30 CAD ASOS. © SAE International
Calculated equivalence ratio and laminar flame speed fields for the considered sL correlations at spark onset (690 CA). © SAE International
Modified Metghalchi and Keck’s correlation relative error map against calculated sL data for gasoline over the considered EC. © SAE International
Experimental flame centroid relative occurrence in terms of displacement along the y-axis. © SAE International

Calculated sL data and polynomial fitting form from Equation 10 (for Φ < 0.7), Equation 4 (for 0.7 ≤ Φ ≤1.4), and Equation 17 (for Φ > 1.4) for gasoline at 19 ECs covering from 5 to 35 bar. Also reported are sL correlations for RMFD-303 gasoline and for RMFD-303 gasoline modified version with lean and rich mixtures’ extensions, limited to their specific validation range. © SAE International
Fitting coefficients for gasoline sL, respectively, valid in the range: 0.7 ≤ Φ ≤ 1.4, Φ > 1.4, and Φ < 0.7 with pressure scaling coefficients. © SAE International
